column2: EU volunteers take part in Karachi’s Sandspit beach cleaning
column3:
KARACHI: The volunteers of European Union in Pakistan and World Wide Fund for Nature – Pakistan (WWF-Pakistan) led a two-day cleaning activity at Sandspit beach.

“Only 10 rivers around the world are responsible for 85% of the plastic pollution of the oceans. Of these, eight rivers are located in Asia, including River Indus,” said EU Ambassador HE Jean-François Cautain.

Speaking at the occasion, Ambassador Cautain said that the EU is committed to increasing awareness about plastic waste and its impact on marine life and the environment. The single-use plastic initiative is part of the EU’s broader Circular Economy agenda, including the world’s first Plastics Strategy, an EU-wide drive towards a more sustainable, circular economy.

As part of the Plastics Strategy, the EU has committed itself to look into further action to address marine litter that builds on the efforts underway in EU member states. He said, “The problem of marine litter is global by nature as it moves in the marine environment and adversely affects marine life.”

More than 70 volunteers from WWF-Pakistan and EU participated in the event. A total of 300 mangrove saplings were also planted while 100 bags of garbage were collected by the participants.

WWF-Pakistan Regional Head for Sindh and Balochistan Dr Babar Khan informed that Pakistan is among the top ten countries affected by climate change and one of the simplest actions citizens can take is to help increase the forest cover of the country, one tree at a time.

“Turtles maintain the health of the sea and removing them from the waters negatively impacts the marine ecosystem,” Dr Khan said. According to an estimate, there are more than 3,000 turtle nests on Sandspit.

column2: Circular Economy policies and changing corporate practices: conceptualizations and empirical evidence
column3: Lecture in the framework of the public lecture series Social Enterprise and Social Innovation Against the backdrop of current political debates around the implementation of Circular Economy principles in the EU, our research investigates how firms and organizations respond to these imperatives and to what extent common practices tend to change. The lecture will first introduce the conceptual and methodological framing of this research question before presenting preliminary findings from case study research in Luxembourg and Sweden, conducted in the building sector, the automotive industry as well as across a diverse range of community/transition initiatives. Christian Schulz works as a Full Professor in the Institute of Geography and Spatial Planning at the University of Luxembourg since 2006. Trained as an economic geographer in Germany, France and Canada, he received a double Master’s degree from the University of the Saarland (Germany) and from the University of Metz (France). Together with Julia Affolderbach (Hull/UK) he recently published the book Green Building Transitions: Regional Trajectories of Innovation in Europe, Canada and Australia (Springer, 2018). He currently works on sustainability transitions with a focus on the challenges and opportunities of post-growth dynamics. The lecture series 'Social Enterprise and Social Innovation' explores social innovation and social enterprise as approach to address environmental and social challenges of sustainability. Diverse legal, financial and business models, and stakeholder relations aspects are discussed. One overarching theme is defining, measuring and reporting on the common good and sustainable value creation in a pluralist society.

column2: Urban waste flows and their potential for a circular economy model at city-region level
column3:
To enable cities to become more circular, i.e. close material cycles, decision-makers need detailed data about the production and treatment of waste. At city level, conventional statistics on waste are often incomplete or lack detail. Waste input-output accounting offers an alternative, using waste supply and use tables to create detailed inventories of economy-wide flows of waste. In this study we develop such tables for the city-region of Brussels (Belgium) and use them to analyse the urban waste metabolism in terms of waste flows, waste production intensity and waste treatment performance.

The waste flow analysis revealed: the amount of collected waste; the proportion contributed by individual sectors; the material composition of waste flows and the location of treatment. Currently, around 50% of the 1.5 million tons of waste collected in Brussels is treated in local facilities. However, less than 1% of the collected waste is used in a way that closes material cycles within city limits. The waste performance analysis reveals that the construction sector had the highest waste production intensity and the household sector the highest incineration intensity. In terms of waste prevention and local valorisation potential, we identified flows and sectors for future targeting, one of the most promising being food waste. We conclude that the urban context can restrict the local valorisation of waste flows, thus we see the role of cities such as Brussels in a circular economy as mainly contributing to the closing of material cycles at national or even global level.

column2: EFT Consult launches Circular Economy Club in Swansea
column3:
Around 25 professionals gathered for Wales’ first global online festival last week dedicated to bringing together the circular economy community from across South West Wales. The event helped organisations understand the theory and application behind the concept of the circular economy.

EFT Consult, a specialist in building services design consultancy and the implementation of the principles of the circular economy, officially launched the Circular Economy Club in Swansea on 14th November 2018 with the support of 4theRegion – a new regional engagement project for South West Wales.

Held at the new Construction Wales Innovation Centre at the University of Wales Trinity Saint David Waterfront Campus in SA1, the event brought together professionals and businesses interested in sustainability, the bio-based economy, the built environment, valorisation of waste, and the Well-being of Future Generations (Wales) Act 2015.

The Well-being of Future Generations (Wales) Act 2015 is the first act of its type in the world that puts the well-being of people, resources and the planet at the heart of policy, key-decision-making and shared resource-values.

As part of the event, attendees were shown a number of inspiring short films curated by the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, and discussed the progress the region is making towards implementing a circular economy strategy for future generations to benefit from now and in the future.

The Circular Economy is an alternative to the current linear model of take, make, waste. It is designed to help organisations be more prudent with their use of resources – to reuse, recycle, regenerate, and care for the well-being of people, resources and the planet.

The Circular Economy Club (CEC) is a non-profit international network of over 2,600 circular economy professionals and organisations in over 60 countries. The CEC is headquartered in London, coordinated by volunteers.

EFT Consult, is the official organiser of the Circular Economy Club in the City & County of Swansea, reflecting the company’s determination to help the regional economy become more circular and sustainable for generations to come.

Through its work with companies and organisations in the built environment across Wales and beyond, EFT deploys circular economy principles to help building owners and managers manage, maintain and renovate their facilities in line with the Well-being of Future Generations (Wales) Act 2015.

Dave Kieft, managing director of EFT Consult, said “Circular Economy practices are not only beneficial to people and the environment, but offer cost-savings and efficiencies for all businesses and organisations in our region, as well as aligning them with the law in terms of the Well-being of Future Generations Act. It is an economic, social and environmental ‘no-brainer’ that we move our economy towards a circular model, which is why we have formed the Swansea Circular Economy Club and intend to play our part in encouraging everyone to take the principles on board.”

Adrian Matthews, Circular Economy consultant at EFT, added “The beauty of the Circular Economy model is that it serves the well-being of everyone in a sustainable way. Businesses can grow and be environmentally responsible, in a way that also helps to regenerate businesses and the economy – through circular economy and well-being principles, through local sourcing, and through the use sustainable materials, products and services.”

Dawn Lyle, founder of 4theRegion, who facilitated the event, said “We see the move towards a circular economy as a fundamental part of how our regional economy develops over the next few years. There are great rewards at stake for businesses and regions prepared to lead the way in embracing circular economy principles. That’s the message, and that’s why we’re so keen to make sure everyone knows what the Circular Economy means and is engaged in the challenge.”

column2: How to define the quality of materials in a circular economy?
column3: Improving the circularity of our economy calls for easily quantifiable metrics that allow us to track our progress towards circularity. We propose the use of a material quality indicator based on the energy use of recycled products versus their counterparts produced from primary material inputs only. We argue that such an indicator can cover at least the environmental dimension of the circular economy in a sufficient way and is therefore useful for the assessment of the circularity of our economy.

column2: What are the most significant aspects of supporting the circular economy in the plastic industry?
column3: Plastic is an indispensable material to our everyday life. However, some negative properties, for example, the durability under mild conditions, pose threat to the natural environment. The circular economy is an effort to mimic the loop-closing attribute of nature in anthropogenic systems. To bring plastics in such circularity in term of circular economy, a number of issues have to be handled from the quality of the recycled material to the acceptance of its use in new products. It is sometimes only a subtle step what we can do easily.

column2: Tailoring Hydrocarbon Polymers and All‐Hydrocarbon Composites for Circular Economy
column3:
The world population will rapidly grow from 7 to 9 billion by 2050 and this will parallel a surging annual plastics consumption from today's 350 million tons to well beyond 1 billion tons. The switch from a linear economy with its throwaway culture to a circular economy with efficient reuse of waste plastics is therefore mandatory. Hydrocarbon polymers, accounting for more than half the world's plastics production, enable closed‐loop recycling and effective product‐stewardship systems. High‐molar‐mass hydrocarbons serve as highly versatile, cost‐, resource‐, eco‐ and energy‐efficient, durable lightweight materials produced by solvent‐free, environmentally benign catalytic olefin polymerization. Nanophase separation and alignment of unentangled hydrocarbon polymers afford 100% recyclable self‐reinforcing all‐hydrocarbon composites without requiring the addition of either alien fibers or hazardous nanoparticles. Recycling of durable hydrocarbons is far superior to biodegradation. The facile thermal degradation enables liquefaction and quantitative recovery of low molar mass hydrocarbon oil and gas. Teamed up with biomass‐to‐liquid and carbon dioxide‐to‐fuel conversions, powered by renewable energy, waste hydrocarbons serve as renewable hydrocarbon feedstocks for the synthesis of high molar mass hydrocarbon materials. Herein, an overview is given on how innovations in catalyst and process technology enable tailoring of advanced recyclable hydrocarbon materials meeting the needs of sustainable development and a circular economy.

Today, plastics are indispensable in economy and daily life. Unparalleled by other materials they are exceptionally versatile with respect to tailoring property profiles from steel‐like to rubbery, permeable/impermeable, durable/biodegradable, facile processing with short cycle times, energy‐and resource‐efficient production, recycling, and wide range of applications. They exploit virtually any kind of carbon source like oil, gas, biomass, waste plastics, and even the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide as raw material to produce advanced materials and materials systems which help to satisfy the elemental human needs for shelter, clothing, health, protection, mobility, communication, and safe supply of food, medicine, water, and energy.1 As highly cost‐, energy‐, and resource‐efficient multifunctional materials they render high tech affordable for everybody living in industrialized as well as developing countries. In manifold ways plastics innovations offer solutions to problems facing the rapidly growing world population which is expected to increase from 7 billion to more than 9 billion by 2050. Plastics are highly beneficial to society. Plastics packaging is essential for food safety, storage, distribution, and reduces food waste.2 In climate protection polymeric thermal insulators and lightweight engineering plastics contribute to significant energy savings accompanied by reduced emission of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide.3, 4 In health care functional polymers enable controlled drug release, protect humans against bacterial attack, and are components of implants, dental fillings, artificial hips, disposable syringes, blood bags, cosmetics, and numerous medical devices‐like sensors.5-8 Durability and safety rely on corrosion protection by coatings which safeguard metals even in a maritime environment.9-11 Polymer membranes are being employed in blood purification by artificial kidneys, water desalination and purification, recovery of metal wastes, separation of chemicals, and even in energy harvesting by means of fuel cells.8, 12-14 Without polymers as electrical insulators transportation of electrical energy would not be feasible.15, 16 Moreover, human comfort and leisure strongly benefits polymer innovations like functional textiles, lightweight engineering plastics, and formulated systems.17, 18 In view of the countless benefits of plastics innovations to society it is not surprising that the growth of plastics consumption, unlike steel and wood, closely follows the rapid growth of the world population.19 Since people living in developing countries aspire high living standards of industrialized countries the demand for plastics will continue to rise at a rapid pace from around 15 million tons in 1965 and today's 350 million tons to well above 1 billion tons in 50 years. At present around 4 wt% of oil and gas, most of which are derived from non‐renewable resources, are consumed as raw materials in plastics industry while further 4 wt% generate energy for plastics manufacturing and distribution.20 This percentage will drastically increase to more than 20 wt% with the surging plastics production which prompts new challenges for exploiting renewable feedstocks including waste plastics. Most polymers are durable, survive hundreds of years in the environment and slowly degrade to form micro plastics. Every year million tons of plastic litter end up in the oceans.21-27 Marine littering is an alarming signal and demands to move away from linear economy to circular economy and high energy‐ and resource‐efficiency in plastics production without sacrificing plastics' performance and cost‐efficiency. According to the Ellen Mc Arthur Foundation plastics packaging accounts for more than 26% of the total volume of plastics used but less than 14% of the waste packaging is collected for recycling.28 In fact, the global recycling rate of plastics is even much lower with respect to packaging and contrary to the higher global recycling rates for paper (58%) and iron and steel (70–90%). Each year, at least 8 million tons of plastics leak into the ocean which is equivalent to dumping the contents of one garbage truck into the ocean every minute. It is estimated that over 150 million tons of plastics are floating in the ocean today. The ocean is expected to contain 1 ton of plastic for every 3 ton of fish by 2025, and by 2050, more plastics than fish (by weight). To ensure that there exists enough natural resources like oil, gas, clean air, potable water, fertile soil, minerals, rare metals, wood, and biodiversity, the switch from a linear to a circular economy is mandatory. For a long period of time in linear economy, driven by burning fossil fuels, raw materials are converted into products which after completing their life cycle are thrown away. This continued reckless depletion of natural resources accompanied by massive emissions of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and marine littering drastically impairs the life of future generations and could trigger a sudden collapse of the biosphere. In 1972 the Club of Rome already pointed out the limits of growth. The period of cheap and plentiful resources is over and the throw‐away culture must end.29-33 As illustrated in Figure 1 there exists two different pathways toward circular economy. In an euphoric bio‐economy vision, biomass utilization, genetic engineering, and biotechnology are seen as the Holy Grail in a bright future.32 In 2012 within the context of sustainable development the UN Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro (“Rio + 20”) endorsed the concept of building a prosperous and strong “greenish” world bio‐economy. In the politicians' and environmentalists' bio‐economy dreams solar power drives bio‐economy converting the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide and water into biomass, which then serves as a feedstock for biofuels, biopower, and bioplastics. Upon thermal or bio‐degradation water and carbon dioxide are recycled. Although this combined use of renewable energy and renewable resources paralleled by switching from fossil to renewable resources is highly appealing to everybody severe problems are encountered. Dreams and reality of green polymer chemistry and bio‐plastics do not match.34 On one hand, only agricultural and forestry wastes should be used as renewable resources for bio‐based plastics to avoid conflicts and competition with food production which is in urgent demand with respect to feeding the rapidly growing world population. Furthermore, stepping up farming to serve the needs of bio‐economy could release massive amounts of carbon dioxide stored in the soil of swamps and forests. This could drastically accelerate global warming. On the other hand, biopolymers and biodegradable plastics are not true alternatives for synthetic polymers. The most abundant biopolymers such as cellulose and chitin are not melt‐processable and their use in polymer applications frequently requires chemical modifications many of which fail to meet the green chemistry requirements. Contrary to natural polymers, bio‐based synthetic polymers are derived from monomers produced by fermentation in bio‐refineries. However, they are produced by traditional polymer syntheses to meet the specific needs of polymer processing and applications. In fact, the extraordinary precision of biosynthesis like in protein engineering is rather problematic regarding tailoring melt‐processable plastics. Even transgenic plants and genetically modified bacteria fail to tailor broad molar mass distributions which enable shear thinning and melt strengthening in extrusion and blow molding. Moreover, the prospects of biodegradation and bio‐plastics in circular economy are limited for several reasons. First, biodegradation is highly sensitive to the climate. In landfill biopolymers similar to synthetic polymers do not degrade in the absence of water and oxygen. Even in a marine environment and in the biosphere biopolymers can have long life time. In landfill bio wastes pose a risk of emitting the greenhouse gas methane under anaerobic conditions. Second, biodegradation does not instantaneously and quantitatively convert bio‐wastes into carbon dioxide and water. For example, bio‐erosion of biopolymers and bio‐based polymers like polylactic acid can account for the formation of fine dust‐like particles which can cause emission and inhalation problems in cities. Furthermore, biodegradable particles serve as breeding ground for bacteria and other microorganisms. Third, biodegradation is counterproductive with respect to recycling since the illusion of biocompatibility and harmless biodegradation promotes reckless littering which is not restricted to bio‐based packaging. Therefore, substituting durable synthetic polymers for bio‐degradable and bio‐based polymers is no viable alternative to recycling. Circular economy goes well beyond the limited scope of bio‐economy and biopolymers. Key feature of circular economy is preventing waste by making products and materials more efficient and reusing them. Plastic wastes serve as raw material for both polymer processing in mechanical recycling and substitution of non‐renewable oil and gas in feedstock recycling. As a rule, all materials must be obtained sustainably without inflicting damage to the environment and human health. Rethinking the complex value chain of a low‐carbon, resource‐ and energy‐efficient plastics economy requires a combined effort of plastics manufacturers, retailers, recyclers, consumers, and politicians. In 2015, the European Commission adopted the EU Action Plan for a sustainable circular plastics economy demanding that the design and production of sustainable plastics and plastic products should address reuse, repair, and recycling.35, 36 In 2017, the Commission confirmed the focus on plastics production with the target of achieving 100% recycling of plastic packaging by 2030.37 An important challenge in sustainable circular economy is to develop environmentally friendly and sustainable plastics with improved performance and facile recycling without drastically impairing favorable economy. Particularly, recyclable all‐polymer composites in which matrix and reinforcing phases are made of the same polymer represent attractive sustainable alternatives to conventional composites containing polymers together with inorganic fibers and fillers. This overview highlights how breakthroughs in catalytic olefin polymerization and polyolefin processing create new generations of 100% recyclable hydrocarbon polymers and all‐hydrocarbon composites which satisfy the needs of the growing world population and meet the demands of circular economy.

In manifold ways hydrocarbon polymers like polyethylene and polypropylene, which account for more than half of the world plastics production and more than 90% of packaging materials, hold great promise regarding circular economy and sustainable development.38 They are produced in environmentally friendly and highly energy‐, resource,‐ and cost‐efficient catalytic processes without solvents and without by‐product formation using virtually any kind of carbon source as raw material ranging from oil, gas, and coal to biomass, waste plastics, and even the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide. Moreover, the exothermic olefin polymerization generates energy due to the high heat of polymerization of 3.34 MJ kg−1. As a solid modification of oil, which is a liquid low molar mass hydrocarbon, high molar mass hydrocarbon polymers possess high fuel‐like high energy content of 40 MJ kg−1. By varying catalyst compositions and process parameters hydrocarbon polymers are readily tailored to meet the demands of highly diversified applications like automotive bumpers, fatigue‐resistant pipes, food packaging, functional textiles, elastomers, furniture, and household appliances. Figure 2 illustrates the principle of hydrocarbon‐based circular economy for polyethylene. Oil, gas, biomass, waste plastics, and carbon dioxide are converted into ethylene gas which is polymerized in gas phase on highly active catalysts to produce melt‐processable polyethylene. At the end of the product life, the resulting waste hydrocarbons serve as raw materials for melt processing, feedstock recovery, and energy recycling. Upon heating above 300 °C in the absence of oxygen carbon–carbon bonds are cleaved and thermal degradation converts the solid hydrocarbons into liquid oil‐like and gaseous low molar mass hydrocarbons in essentially quantitative yields. Polymer pyrolysis consumes energy which is around 5 MJ kg−1. As is apparent from polymer pyrolysis investigations by Kaminsky (see Table 1), the thermal conversion of waste polyolefins like polyethylene (PE) and polypropylene (PP) into oil and gas is much more efficient with respect to biopolymers such as cellulose and lignin which produce considerably less oil and gas together with much higher amounts of residues and water.39-41 Most other commodity and engineering thermoplastics also represent valuable sources of renewable oil and gas gained by catalytic and non‐catalytic thermolysis. Variations of catalysts and process parameters increase the yield of liquid hydrocarbons and even allow for the recovery of 1‐olefins.41, 42 In the presence of small amounts of oxygen the partial oxidation in conjunction with gasification affords a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen which serves as syngas producing a variety of raw materials including oil‐like hydrocarbons obtained by the much more energy‐intensive Fischer–Tropsch process established in coal‐to‐liquid as well as biomass‐to‐liquid processes.43 Recovery of oil and gas by non‐catalytic polymer thermolysis Al‐Salem et al. gave an overview on the extraordinary versatility of polyolefins with respect to efficient material, feedstock, and energy recycling.44 While clean production wastes qualify for material recycling by remolding, polluted wastes of lower hydrocarbon quality are efficiently recycled by thermo‐chemical treatments to produce either fuels or petrochemical feedstocks. In municipal waste incineration polyolefin wastes serve as energy source due to their high energy content. According to Panda et al. the thermolytic conversion of polymer waste plastics to liquid fuel represents a viable process for plastics waste management.45 As compared to non‐catalytic thermolysis of waste polyolefin the addition of catalyst such as zeolites and mesoporous silica affords a better control of the ratio of liquid‐to‐gas‐to‐solid residue ratio as well as of the hydrocarbon branching and content of aromatics at milder temperatures below 450 °C.46-54 Serrano et al. developed hierarchical zeolites with bimodal micropore/mesopore size distribution which are highly active catalysts for polymer cracking.55 They favor a two‐step process which combines thermolysis with subsequent catalytic conversion to avoid catalyst poisoning by impurities. Also blends of hydrocarbon polymers and biomass are successfully employed in feedstock recovery by means of thermolysis.56 In principle, catalytic and non‐catalytic waste polyolefin thermolysis could team up with biomass‐to‐liquid conversion (“bio‐oil” and “bio‐diesel”)57-61 by catalytic thermolysis. In fact, the catalytic thermal liquefaction of waste plastics and waste biomass are highly attractive for recycling since oil has much higher density with respect to fluffy solid wastes and facilitates the transport of raw materials derived from wastes to refineries. In refineries hydrocarbons are attractive with respect to the production of fuels and chemicals. By steam cracking hydrocarbons are converted into ethylene and propylene monomers. The facile on‐board catalytic conversion could help to reduce marine littering by cruise ships which could convert hydrocarbon packaging wastes into diesel fuel. During recent years significant progress has been made with respect to capture of carbon dioxide which is converted into hydrocarbon fuels and olefin monomers. In Brazil sugarcane serves as feedstock for producing bioethanol which is converted into ethylene by catalytic dehydration to produce bio‐based hydrocarbon polymers like Braskem's Green Polyethylene.62 Today, the dream reaction of directly converting the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide into fuels and chemical feedstocks without biomass by‐pass becomes an industrially viable reality. By mimicking natural photosynthesis, sunlight drives the catalytic conversion of carbon dioxide and water into hydrocarbons.63-66 Electroreduction converts carbon dioxide and water into hydrocarbons‐like methane but also enables the formation of hydrocarbon fuels and even ethylene in the presence of copper catalysts.67-69 Exploiting hydrogen produced by electrochemical water splitting carbon dioxide is reduced to methanol using renewable energy. Methanol is an attractive intermediate.70 Albeit hydrocarbons derived from carbon dioxide are not yet competitive with gasoline from fossil resources it holds prospects for solar fuel production and the chemical storage of renewable energy produced by wind mills and photovoltaics.71, 72 However, all these manifold chemical recycling opportunities and alternative waste management systems exploiting carbon dioxide capture and a closed loop scenario require careful evaluation by means of life cycle assessment to compare the economic and environmental impact of renewable chemical feedstocks with fossil resources and energy recycling.73-77 The remarkable and ongoing progress made in polyolefin technology has greatly simplified polyolefin production and sets new standards in environmentally friendly and sustainable industrial polymer syntheses.38 Table 2 outlines the impact of important breakthroughs in polyolefin research and development on circular economy and sustainable development. In the early 1950s Karl Ziegler and the Phillips Petroleum Company discovered transition metal catalysts enabling catalytic low‐pressure ethylene polymerization at ambient temperature whereas free‐radical ethylene polymerization, developed during the 1930s, is much less energy‐efficient due to high polymerization temperatures well above 150 °C and significantly higher ethylene pressure exceeding 1000 bar. Moreover, unparalleled by high‐pressure ethylene polymerization, molar mass, molar mass distribution, end groups, as well as short‐ and long‐chain branching are readily varied as a function of catalyst composition and polymerization process parameters. Today, the spectrum of polyethylenes produced by catalytic ethylene polymerization spans from linear high‐density polyethylene (HDPE) for pipes to linear low density short‐ and long‐chain‐branched polyethylene (LLDPE) for packaging, ethylene/propylene/diene copolymers (EPDM) for rubbers, and ethylene/cycloolefin copolymers for optics and pharmaceutical packaging. In the aftermath of the first oil crisis during the early 1970s, energy efficiency became a successful marketing tool, which was successfully employed by the Union Carbide Corporation to boost LLDPE production well above 1 million tons within just 10 years albeit ethylene copolymers were commercially available since the late 1950s. In 1954 Giulio Natta successfully employed Ziegler's catalyst to polymerize propylene and to produce semi‐crystalline isotactic polypropylene (PP) as cost‐efficient and highly versatile lightweight engineering thermoplastic which exhibits a heat distortion temperature above 100 °C and successfully competes with metals, wood, and other less cost‐efficient engineering plastics. In the pioneering days, owing to the rather low catalyst activities and poor stereoselectivity of the first catalyst generations and slurry polymerization in hydrocarbon diluents, 1 ton of PP was produced together with up to 200 kg of by‐products like amorphous atactic polypropylene and highly corrosive and color forming catalysts residues, both of which were removed by extraction with organic solvents and disposed to landfill. Breakthroughs in catalysis and process technology, namely the discovery of highly active and stereoselective magnesium chloride supported titanium catalysts, have rendered polyolefin production environmentally friendly and highly cost‐, resource‐, eco‐, and energy‐efficient.78-86 With exceptional catalyst activities well above 106 g polyolefin/g titanium, which is equivalent to less than 1 ppm titanium content in the polymer, the non‐toxic catalyst residues are left in the polymer without encountering corrosion, color, and health problems. Moreover, catalytic polymerization on supported catalysts enables polymerization in gas phase and liquid propylene, thus eliminating the use of organic solvents. In modern polypropylene production a few kilograms of hydrocarbon by‐products per ton of PP are recycled in the refinery, no solvent emissions are encountered, and no production wastes end up in landfill. Ethylene polymerization in reactor cascades affords tailored polyethylenes with bimodal molar mass distributions comprising HDPE together with a few percent of ultrahigh molar mass polyethylene (UHMWPE) which serves as tie molecule for HDPE crystallites and significantly improves processing by shear thinning and enhances impact strength, stress crack resistance, tensile strength, and fatigue life of HDPE pipes.87, 88 The PE100 resins withstand a minimum circumferential stress of 10 MPa for 50 years at 20 °C and are particularly useful in highly demanding applications like gas and water distribution.89 Today, bimodal polyethylenes meet pipe industry standards with lighter weight HDPE pipes or pipes with the same wall thickness but significantly wider safety margins. Progress in polyolefin technology and its impact on circular economy and sustainable development No removal of catalyst residues which are left in the polymer (“leave‐in catalysts”) No by‐products like waxes and atactic polypropylene/no polymer purification by solvent extraction Tailoring polyolefins in a single reactor instead of reactor cascades During the 1990s the better insight in polyolefin particle growth and catalyst fragmentation has led to the development of the reactor granule technology like LyondellBasell's Spheripol process for PP and the Spherilene process for PE, producing pellet‐sized polyolefin particles during olefin polymerization.86, 90, 91 Industrial PP cascade reactor systems like LyondellBasell's Catalloy92-94 and Borealis' Borstar process95, 96 combine particle‐forming liquid‐pool stereospecific propylene polymerization in a loop reactor with subsequent ethylene/propylene gas‐phase polymerization to incorporate EPM rubber into reactor granules for improving the toughness/stiffness/strength balance of the resulting PP/EPM reactor blends. Since both PP pelletizing melt extrusion and PP/EPM melt compounding are no longer required, reactor granule technology brings considerable additional energy savings. Moreover, reactor granule technology represents the key to the development of the multizone circulating reactors as another significant innovation in PP production.90, 91, 97 In 2004 LyondellBasell launched the Spherizone process,91, 94, 98-100 to produce spherical PP particles with a tailored molar‐mass distribution in a single‐loop reactor. Growing PP particles circulate between riser and downer zones, which have different polymerization conditions and produce PP with different molar masses inside the growing PP particles. The resulting multimodal PP with ultrahigh melt strength is applied in rigid packaging. Ongoing innovations in catalyst and process technology significantly improved PP versatility and sustainability. During the 1980s the discovery of single‐site catalysts like metallocenes,101-107 constrained‐geometry catalysts,108-110 and post metallocenes111-118 have revolutionized sustainable polyolefin production. The facile variation of the molecular architectures of single‐site catalysts affords unprecedented control of molecular mass, molar mass distribution, branching, comonomer incorporation, and even polyolefin morphologies from the centimeter down to nanometer range. In addition to conventional titanium, vanadium, chromium, nickel, and zirconium catalysts for the first time highly active iron catalysts became available.116, 117, 119-122 Whereas the catalytically active transition metal of conventional catalysts is always allocated at the polyolefin chain end and short chain branching of polyethylene is achieved by ethylene copolymerization with 1‐olefins, LLDPE and even hyperbranched liquid polyethylene are produced by ethylene homopolymerization in the absence of 1‐olefins as comonomers using modern catalysts. In chain‐walking ethylene polymerization on diimine nickel and palladium complexes (Brookhart catalysts) the catalytically active transition metal travels up and down the polymer main and side chain during ethylene polymerization and enables alkyl‐branching.117 The co‐immobilization of early and late transition‐metal catalysts on an methylaluminoxane (MAO)‐tethered silica support affords control of branching using ethylene as the exclusive feedstock.122-125 The absence of 1‐olefin comonomers contributes to energy savings and reduced costs related to the production, transportation, and feed of 1‐olefin in LLDPE manufacturing. Most industrial catalysts for olefin polymerization are severely poisoned by comonomers bearing polar groups which successfully compete with olefins for vacant coordination sites. Today advanced nickel‐ and palladium‐based catalyst generations enable the alternating copolymerization of ethylene with carbon monoxide to produce polyketones126, 127 and the random copolymerization of ethylene with polar vinyl polymers to form polar LLDPE.128, 129 Even ethylene polymerization in water is now feasible.130 This impressive list of breakthroughs in polyolefin technology reveals that ongoing innovations greatly enhance resource‐, energy‐, eco‐, and cost‐efficiency of polyolefin‐based hydrocarbon materials derived from both fossil and renewable resources. Solvent‐free catalytic polymerization and catalytic degradation in conjunction with exceptional versatility in terms of melt processing, tailoring property profiles, applications, and recycling is unparalleled by most other non‐hydrocarbon materials. In an ideal way, recyclable hydrocarbon materials produced by means of catalysis with high atom economy in the absence of solvents and without by‐product formation meet the demands of green chemistry and sustainable development. Therefore, it is not surprising that in life cycle assessment polypropylene was ranked as the number one and polyethylene as the number two far ahead of bio‐based materials including polylactic acid.131

Today, most polymers are reinforced with alien fibers and fillers to improve their toughness/stiffness/strength balance which is essential for the development of lightweight materials in construction, automotive, and aerospace industries. However, high content of inorganic components and additional process steps drastically impair high energy‐, resource‐,and cost‐efficiency of hydrocarbon polymers and their recycling as material, feedstock, and energy source.132-136 Moreover, higher densities of the reinforcing agents account for higher weight with respect to the neat hydrocarbon polymers. In view of circular economy, sustainability, and further reducing weight it is highly desirable to self‐reinforce polymers without requiring the addition of alien materials. In self‐reinforced polymers alias molecular composites alias all‐polymers or one‐component composites, respectively, the polymer matrix is reinforced with fibers or sheets produced by aligning the chains of the same polymer. Preferably, 1D and 2D nanostructures of aligned polymers are formed by shear‐induced polymer crystallization during melt processing and do not require prefabricated nanoparticles as the nanostructures represent an integral part of the entire hydrocarbon polymer structural hierarchy. Moreover, the co‐crystallization of matrix and reinforcing (nano) phase affords excellent interfacial adhesion and efficient stress transfer from the matrix to the fiber‐ and sheet‐like nanostructures. The technical term “molecular composites” describes homogeneous dispersions of a rigid‐rod polymer in a rather flexible coil polymer matrix, albeit the same term has also been used to describe reinforcement of nanocomposites containing nanofillers.137 Today, the most prominent commercial representatives of molecular composites are rather expensive polymers like aramid or generally speaking liquid crystalline polymers (LCP). As pioneered by Keller and coworkers during the 1980s, in the case of all‐PE and all‐PP composites the formation of shish‐kebab structures of extended‐chain hydrocarbon polymers plays an important role.138-140 Another objective is to prepare all‐polymer nanocomposites by means of nanostructure formation which eliminates the use of problematic nanoparticles associated special safety and handling procedures and emission problems. As is illustrated in Figure 3, polymer self‐reinforcement is achieved either by multi‐step processes such as lamination of prefabricated stretched tapes, fabrics, and non‐wovens, or by single‐step processes like melt manipulation and nanophase separation, both of which produce fiber‐ and sheet‐like polymer nanostructures by shear‐induced polymer crystallization during melt processing. Whereas most strategies require special processing and exhibit rather narrow processing windows, nanophase separation of polyethylene rector blends enables self‐reinforcement during conventional polyethylene extrusion and injection molding without drastically affecting the processing window (see Section 4). Progress made in all‐polymer composite development was reviewed by Karger‐Kocsis et al.,141, 142 Alcock and Peijs,143 Fu et al.,144 and Yu et al.145 Routes to one‐component composites via multi‐step processes like hot compaction (welding) of stretched tapes and fibers and via single‐step processes like co‐extrusion, melt manipulation, and nanophase separation of reactor blends which do not require specialized melt processing. In multi‐step processes, which are being applied in commercial scale, polymer alignment is achieved in a separate process step producing prefabricated stretched tapes, fibers, fabrics, and films which are bonded together by means of hot compaction and welding. The basic principle behind all these techniques is to exploit the melt temperature difference between the oriented, highly stretched polymer as the reinforcement and the same non‐oriented polymer as matrix. Typically this difference is lower than 20 °C and implies rather narrow processing windows which require a careful temperature control in melt processing since heating above the melting temperature converts aligned polymers into entangled polymer coils. During the mid‐1970s the concept of producing one‐component hydrocarbon polymers was pioneered by Capiati and Porter who embedded drawn PE fibers into a PE matrix by adding them to PE melts without melting the PE fibers.141 Meanwhile several all‐PP‐composites‐like Curv, Armordon, Para‐Lite, and Pure are commercially available.146 Whereas Curv comprises laminates of PP fabrics embedded in a PP matrix, Pure, Para‐Lite, and Armordon are produced by hot compaction (welding) of stretched tapes. As is illustrated in Figure 4, according to Alcock and Peijs all‐PP composites are produced by laminating co‐extruded PP tapes containing a PP homopolymer core surrounded by a propylene copolymer skin which melts at somewhat lower temperatures with respect to PP core. Since the resulting recyclable hydrocarbon composites contained up to 90% oriented PP they exhibited significantly higher Young's modulus of up to 5.9 GPa as compared to 1.1 GPa for the corresponding non‐oriented PP.147-150 However, the precise temperature control during welding and thermoforming within a narrow processing window is essential as the difference between both melting temperatures is rather small and heating well above the melting temperature of the PP homopolymer melting temperature could cause the collapse of matrix reinforcement due to thermally induced PP stretch/coil transition.149, 151, 152 Most likely due to its brick‐to‐mortar structure resembling nacre, all‐PP composites combine high stiffness and strength with extraordinary damage tolerance as reflected by their outstanding impact resistance.151, 153 As reported by Ward et al. film stacking by hot compaction of fabrics and of co‐extruded tapes with and without interleaved films gave recyclable all‐PP composites with similar mechanical properties.154 High performance all‐PP composites, produced by the incorporation of PP fibers in a random PP copolymer, were also reported by Bárány, Izer, and Czigány.155 By applying the film stacking method the reinforced fibers were incorporated at different temperatures and processing times. They demonstrated that only by processing around 165 °C, very close to the melting temperature of the reinforcing PP phase (171 °C), significant increases of stiffness, strength, and impact resistance were achieved. Additionally, the time for the film stacking was crucial. Too short periods of compaction resulted in insufficient consolidation of matrix and reinforcing phase, while longer processing times exceeding 90 s deteriorated the fiber orientation. Further improvements especially in the flexural creep resistance have been addressed by Banik, Abraham, and Karger‐Kocsis who employed commercially available all‐PP (Pure). Pure itself consists of an ABA structure with an PP homopolymer as the core flanked by random PP‐copolymer skin layers.156 Commercial all‐PP composites processed by thermoforming exhibit remarkably low weight and are extremely strong, highly impact resistant, and 100% recyclable. They are the material of choice for producing light and highly damage‐tolerant suitcases and transport boxes as well as sports equipment like rackets, helmets, ski boots, and shin guards. Figure 5 shows a test car crash with a Samsonite Cosmolite suitcase made of woven PP. While the car is damaged beyond repair the severely dented all‐PP suitcase is highly damage‐tolerant and capable of self‐repair. Unlike the metal of the car body it fully recovers after impact to its original shape. Co‐extrusion of skin/core films or core/shell fibers, respectively, followed by hot compaction to produce all‐hydrocarbon composites. A test car crashes into an all‐PP suitcase which survives the crash unharmed whereas the metal is damaged beyond repair. Samsonite Cosmolite, screen shots taken from the YouTube Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v = FY7e1w1m8cU. Reproduced with permission. Copyright 2011, Samsonite GmbH. Karger‐Kocsis et al. prepared recyclable all‐PP composites by film stacking using PP fabrics as reinforcing phase and α and β polymorphs of isotactic PP homopolymer and random propylene/ethylene copolymers as matrix.157-159 Upon consolidation by hot pressing at 5 and 15 °C above the melting temperature of the PP matrix the use of β‐PP homopolymer afforded improved all‐PP composite performance with respect to propylene/ethylene copolymers. The PP fabric was composed of highly stretched PP homopolymer yarns exhibiting a melting point of 178 °C and a tensile strength of 465 MPa. Both static tensile and dynamic impact response were strongly affected by the consolidation temperature. Stiffness and strength usually increased while impact strength decreased with increasing consolidation temperature. Bocz et al. prepared flame retardant self‐reinforced composites from automotive shredder waste by adding plain woven fabrics (highly stretched split PP tapes) and ammonium polyphosphate (APP, Clariant AG).160 Flame retardancy and reinforcement are potential antagonistic requirements for PP, especially in the case of fiber reinforcement. The authors of the publication argued that multilayer composites of alternating layers of reinforcing PP‐tape and recycled PP‐waste with APP could circumvent this scenario. The automotive waste had a PP content of 78% and a density of 0.92 g cm−3. Benchmarks included compounds without reinforcing, glass fiber reinforced PP and the SRF‐PP. Sample preparation was done by film stacking and compression molding at 162 °C. The mechanical properties of the polyolefin waste were significantly improved by applying reinforcing polypropylene fabrics, resulting in five times higher tensile strength, two times higher flexural strength, and four times higher perforation energy. Although the tensile and flexural strength of the recycled matrix could be more effectively increased by using glass fabric reinforcement, the prepared self‐reinforced composites offered benefits with respect to environmental aspects, taking into account that their density was much lower with respect to glass fiber reinforced composites. Moreover, at the end of their life cycle, all‐PP is easy to recycle by simple reprocessing methods. Additionally, the flame retardancy measured by limiting oxygen index (LOI), UL‐94 testing, and cone calorimetry, showed significant improvement by the addition of 18 wt% APP.161 Alcock et al. analyzed in their studies the mechanical properties of unidirectional all‐PP composites.147 By co‐extrusion of a three‐layer tape (density of 0.732 g cm−3 due to micro voids) and by winding the tapes around a steel plate unidirectional oriented precursor structures were obtained. By carefully controlling the temperature in the hot compaction process, it was seen that the exterior of polymer fibers could be melted and with the simultaneous application of pressure, this molten polymer flows to fill the interfibrillar voids. Upon cooling, this recrystallized material formed the matrix phase of the composite. By this method “highly filled” composites (90% fibers) were obtained and exhibited similar properties to that of glass‐fiber filled composites (Young's modulus of 13 GPa, tensile strength of 370 MPa, and elongation at break of 8%) but much lower density of 0.77 g cm−3. This lower density combined with matrix reinforcement represents the special feature of all‐PP composites with high content of oriented PP and is characteristic for the hot compaction method. The low transverse composite strength was attributed to the tape geometry and especially to the high orientation. Since the width of the tape was about 36 times greater than the thickness of the tape, a large overlap in the transverse direction was present, thus providing extensive load transfer between tapes. Alcock et al. employed the hot compaction method to produce several families of recyclable all‐PP composites.149, 151, 153, 162, 163 In an alternative process, they obtained recyclable all‐PP composites by co‐extrusion and direct drawing of tapes without hot compaction.162 Opposite to two‐step processes which require prefabrication of oriented hydrocarbon polymers single processes exploit flow‐induced 1D and 2D crystallization of semi‐crystalline hydrocarbon polymers during melt processing combined with melt manipulation to achieve high elongational flow. As is illustrated in Figure 6, Ehrenstein and coworkers employed a convergent die with high elongational flow to generate HDPE shish which nucleated HDPE crystallization to form shish‐kebab‐like polyethylene structures as reinforcing phases.141, 164-167 However, only when the processing temperature was very close to the HDPE melting temperature relaxation and coil recovery were prevented at high extrusion pressure. According to Keller et al. the high molar mass tail of the HDPE molar mass distribution accounted for the formation of extended‐chain HDPE fibrils which formed the backbones of the shish‐kebab structures as reinforcing phases, whereas the lower molar mass HDPE affected melt strength and extrudability.140 As reviewed by Hsiao et al. variations of processing conditions affected HDPE morphologies and properties but according to in situ rheo‐X‐ray studies and microscopy self‐reinforcement was attributed to shish‐kebab structure formation.168 Shish‐kebab structures with multiple shish were observed at elevated UHMWPE content. Ryan et al. investigated the parameters governing shish‐kebab structure formation of bimodal polyethylene model systems obtained by solution blending of hydrogenated poly(1,4‐butadiene) as polyethylene model compounds.169-172 To enable the formation of oriented HDPE nuclei the shear rate should be higher than the inverse Rouse time of the longest chain and the mechanical work should exceed a critical threshold. At that time the state‐of‐the‐art catalyst technology did not permit to vary the HDPE molar mass distribution over a wide range as the incorporation of more than 3 wt% UHMWPE drastically increased melt viscosity and disabled melt extrusion due to massive entanglement. By using a convergent extrusion die and an extrusion pressure varied between 20 and 60 MPa, Huang et al. produced self‐reinforced HDPE173 and PP.174 From mechanical and tribological investigation they identified mechanical anisotropy of self‐reinforced HDPE.175 In addition to convergent dies a great variety of highly specialized injection molding processes (see Figure 7) like dynamic packing injection molding (DPIM),176-180 oscillating packing injection molding (OPIM),181, 182 shear‐controlled orientation in injection molding (SCORIM),183-191 and vibration injection molding (VIM)189, 192-196 have been developed to produce self‐reinforced hydrocarbon polymers. Due to the existence of oriented shish‐kebab structures in flow‐direction Young's modulus and tensile strength simultaneously increased from 1 GPa and 23 MPa to 5 GPa and 93 MPa, respectively.182 Chen and Shen processed a PP homopolymer by OPIM. Their mechanical analysis showed increased yield stress and perforation energy by increasing fiber content. All specialized one‐ and multi‐step melt processing methods for manufacturing of all‐hydrocarbon composite exhibit rather narrow processing windows and significantly increase costs with respect to melt processing of commodity hydrocarbon polymers like PP and HDPE. New generations of hydrocarbon polymers tailored with advanced catalyst systems enable to fabricate all‐hydrocarbon composite by conventional injection molding, extrusion, and blow molding without impairing high cost efficiency typical for commodity all‐hydrocarbon composites.

Recent progress made in olefin polymerization catalysis enables to tailor unentangled, aligned, and nanophase‐separated ultrastrong fiber‐ and sheet‐like nanostructured hydrocarbon polymers as well as the corresponding all‐hydrocarbon composites. Among hydrocarbon polymers UHMWPE is well known to exhibit an exceptional combination of ultrahigh toughness and abrasion resistance unparalleled by most other non‐modified engineering thermoplastics. However, their massive entanglement accounts for drastically higher melt viscosity which is not tolerated by injection molding. Hence, UHMWPE powders are processed by sintering. Gel‐spinning was developed to produce ultrastrong fibers of extended‐chain UHMWPE exhibiting superior strength with respect to steel.200 Chanzy et al. pioneered tailoring of unentangled ultrahigh molar mass polyethylene by means of catalytic ethylene polymerization (see Figure 8 left). They produced UHMWPE films and high modulus/high strength UHMWPE filaments and tapes drawn directly from virgin unentangled UHMWPE without requiring solvents and gel processing.201-203 Going beyond the industrially limited scope of vanadium catalysts supported on a glass plate used in this first proof of concept, Rastogi et al. have employed advanced single site catalyst systems to prepare UHMWPE and UHMWPE reactor blends in the unentangled state to achieve high modulus and strength by drawing.204-213 Aida et al. obtained UHMWPE nanofibers with a diameter of 30 to 50 nm by ethylene polymerization referred to as “extrusion polymerization” on mesoporous silica supported titanocene catalysts (see Figure 8 right).214 However, this catalyst systems does not meet the demands of catalyst fragmentation and morphology control characteristic for industrial catalyst systems. Particularly, as shown in Figure 9, ethylene polymerization on quinolylsilylcyclopentadienyl chromium (III) half sandwich sites producing UHMWPE with molar mass >106 g mol−1 combined with bisiminopyridine iron (II) sites producing HDPE and bisiminopyridyl chromium (III) sites producing HDPE wax with low molar mass of 103 g mol−1 allows for tailoring trimodal PE molar mass distributions in which the ratio of the three different catalytically active complexes governs the weight ratio of polyethylene fractions having different molar masses.216 Moreover, the average molar masses of the individual fractions are unaffected by the catalyst composition and enable efficient control of trimodal distributions in both lab and industrial scale. As is illustrated in Figure 10, the unentangled UHMWPE nanophase separates during ethylene polymerization on multisite‐catalysts to form nanoplatelet‐like and spongy structures. However, it should be noted that no hazardous UHMWPE nanoparticles are formed since UHMWPE nanostructures represent an integral part of the entire polyethylene structure. During melt processing by means of extrusion and injection molding, using machines and processing parameters typical for melt processing of commodity HDPE, the nanophase‐separated UHMWPE melts and the resulting UHMWPE melt is elongated by shear forces to form extended‐chain nanofiber‐like structures which nucleate the crystallization HDPE and HDPE wax to form shish‐kebab structures as reinforcing phases of the HDPE matrix. Further improvement of the toughness/stiffness/strength balance was achieved by using reduced graphene oxide as support which was dispersed as carbon nanofiller within the nanostructured reactor blend.220 The incorporation of HDPE wax serves as processing aid which lowers melt viscosity and enables to increase the amount of UHMWPE, paralleled by improved mechanical performance, without sacrificing melt processability by injection molding.221, 222 Unlike HDPE wax addition restricted to less than 1 wt% in conventional HDPE, the UHMWPE/HDPE reactor blend tolerated significant amounts of HDPE wax without encountering massive odor, color, and emission problems due to the highly efficient co‐crystallization of HDPE wax which is incorporated into the kebab structures. The morphology development was imaged by means of SEM analysis of virgin reactor blend powders (see Figure 11 left) and injection molded reactor blends (see Figure 11 center) etched with hot xylene. While the powder comprises platelet‐like and spongy nanostructures the injection molded reactor blends exhibit shish‐kebab‐fiber‐like structures containing extended‐chain UHMWPE as shish. Upon annealing the injection‐molded reactor blends above the HDPE melting temperature but below the melting temperature of the extended‐chain UHMWPE, followed by rapid quenching to prevent HDPE crystallization, removal of amorphous HDPE by hot xylene extraction revealed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis that extended chain nanofiber‐like UHMWPE structures with average diameter below 100 nm were formed.223 Such UHMWPE nanofibers are unavailable by gel spinning. An important challenge in the twenty‐first century is to satisfy the needs of the rapidly growing world population which is expected to increase from 7 to 9 billion by 2050. In manifold ways plastics help to meet the basic human demands for shelter, clothing, health, mobility, communication and secure transport of food, water, medicine, and energy. All people living in industrialized and developing countries aspire the same high quality of life which is intimately connected with the surging demand for plastics. In fact, the annual growth of plastics production closely parallels the exponential growth of world population and is expected to rise from around 15 million in 1964 and today's 350 million tons to well above 1 billion tons in 2050. Whereas more than one‐third of the durable plastics are consumed in short‐lived packaging much less than 20 wt% of packaging materials are recycled. In fact, the global recycling rate for plastics is drastically lower with respect to that for paper (58%) and iron and steel (70–90%). Marine littering is just one of the alarming signals for accumulation of durable waste plastics in the biosphere when recycling fails. The switch from the throw‐away culture in linear economy to circular economy with recycling and a more efficient use of renewable resources and renewable energy is mandatory. Today, the European waste management relies on landfill, incineration, and mechanical recycling, whereas feedstock recycling plays an insignificant role. This may change since waste hydrocarbons are attractive raw materials and available in large quantities which make feedstock recycling much more attractive. In 2015 the European Commission had initiated the transition from linear to circular plastics economy and plans to achieve 100% recycling of waste packaging by 2030. Among plastics hydrocarbon materials like polyolefins account for more than half of the plastics production and a large portion of waste packaging. They offer attractive prospects regarding establishing both closed‐loop recycling and efficient product‐stewardship systems. Key feature is their efficient transition between liquid and solid state as a function of their molar mass. Additionally, both high and low molar mass hydrocarbons have similar fuel‐like high energy content. High molar mass hydrocarbons serve as highly versatile, cost‐, resource‐, eco,‐ and energy‐efficient, durable lightweight materials produced by highly efficient solvent‐free environmentally benign catalytic olefin polymerization. Olefin monomers are readily gained from virtually any carbon sources ranging from oil, gas, and coal to bioethanol, biomass, waste plastics, and even carbon dioxide. Upon completing their product life, waste hydrocarbon can be funneled into all pathways established for material, feedstock, and energy recycling. In view of the rapidly increasing amount of hydrocarbon wastes their reuse as renewable source of hydrocarbon oil and gas is gaining attractiveness especially as an alternative to energy recycling by incineration accompanied by carbon dioxide emissions. Thermolysis readily cleaves carbon–carbon bonds and quantitatively converts solid hydrocarbon materials into low molecular weight hydrocarbon oil and gas useful as chemical feedstock and source of energy. This quantitative conversion is unparalleled by biopolymers and synthetic polymers containing heteroatoms. The liquefaction of waste hydrocarbon materials facilitates the transport of wastes to refineries. In principle, delocalized thermolysis combined with centralized refining offers prospects for efficient waste management and feedstock recycling. Teamed up with biomass‐to‐liquid and carbon dioxide‐to‐fuel conversions, powered by renewable energy, liquefied waste hydrocarbons serve as renewable hydrocarbon feedstocks for producing chemicals, polymers, and fuels. The use of durable hydrocarbon materials in closed‐loop hydrocarbon economy is far superior to bio‐economy based on biodegradable plastics and biopolymers. Biodegradation depends on the climate and is counterproductive regarding the efficient reuse of polymers as it fosters dumping wastes in the environment. In the absence of water and oxygen also biodegradable plastics can survive for decades in the environment. In landfill they pose a risk of emitting the greenhouse gas methane by anaerobic biodegradation. Moreover, most bio‐based plastics and biopolymers do not instantaneously decompose to form carbon dioxide and water. The dream of closed‐loop bio‐recycling using the conversion of water and carbon dioxide into biomaterials which decompose quantitatively to recover water and carbon dioxide is far away from the reality. Biodegradation is frequently accompanied by bio‐erosion producing micro‐bioplastics which are carried away by wind and water. They serve as breeding grounds for bacteria and other microorganisms and can pollute the air in cities. Biodegradable polymers are attractive for niche markets but in contrast to hydrocarbon polymers do not offer environmentally friendly global solutions for packaging waste problems. Furthermore, it should be noted that solventless hydrocarbon gas phase processes offer advantages with respect to biosynthesis in water. Manufacturing of paper is not a green process and much less environmentally friendly with respect to polyethylene synthesis. Hydrocarbon polymers like polyethylene and polypropylene have low carbon footprint and are the clear leaders in the world production of plastics and also in life cycle assessment. This is due to the remarkable progress made in polyolefin manufacturing. During the late 1950s the production of 1 ton of polypropylene yielded up to 200 kg of by‐products like atactic polypropylene which was removed by solvent extraction together with corrosive catalyst residues, both of which were deposited in landfill. Today, exceptionally active and selective catalysts polymerize olefins in gas phase or liquid monomer with yields exceeding 1 ton polyolefin per 1 g transition metals without formation of wax‐like polymers as by‐products. Hence, purification and solvent recycling steps were eliminated. Moreover, reactor‐granule technology produces pellet‐shaped hydrocarbon particles during polymerization and does not require pelletizing melt‐extrusion. Unprecedented control of molar mass and branching distribution of polyethylene significantly improved the lifetime of gas and water pipes and reduced the weight of hydrocarbon packaging. The ongoing breakthroughs in catalyst and process technologies allow for facile tailoring of advanced hydrocarbon polymers for circular economy. In a recent advance nanophase separation and alignment of unentangled hydrocarbon polymers has afforded 100% recyclable and highly damage‐tolerant all‐hydrocarbon composites processed by injection molding typical for commodity polyolefins without requiring the addition of either alien fibers or hazardous nanoparticles. While composites containing alien fibers are problematic in recycling, self‐reinforced nanostructured all‐hydrocarbon composites produced by ethylene polymerization on multisite catalysts are readily recycled as material by repeated remolding, as feedstock by thermolysis of wastes or as source of energy. Today, commodity hydrocarbon polymers are being converted into high performance hydrocarbon materials without sacrificing their economic benefits, high energy and resource efficiency, low weight, durability, and extraordinary versatility in terms of tailoring property profiles, facile processing, wide range of applications, and recycling. In an ideal way fully recyclable and versatile all‐hydrocarbon materials with low carbon footprint make efficient use of resources and satisfy the needs of the growing world population for low cost advanced materials, green chemistry, sustainability, and circular economy.
